net.fathomsoft.fathom.tree.variables

Class VariableNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.fathomsoft.fathom.tree.TreeNode
      • net.fathomsoft.fathom.tree.ValueNode
        • net.fathomsoft.fathom.tree.IdentifierNode
          • net.fathomsoft.fathom.tree.variables.VariableNode
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArrayNode, InstanceDeclarationNode, LocalVariableNode

    public class VariableNode
extends IdentifierNode
    ModifierNode extension that represents the declaration of a variable node type. Harnesses the needed information of each variable, such as whether or not it is constant, external, or an array, and its type.
    Since:
    v0.1 Jan 5, 2014 at 9:02:42 PM
    Version:
    v0.2.4 May 17, 2014 at 9:55:04 PM
    Author:
    Braden Steffaniak

      • isExternal

        public boolean isExternal()
        Get whether or not the variable is external. For more information on external variables, see setExternal(boolean).
        Returns:
        Whether or not the variable is external.

      • setExternal

        public void setExternal(boolean external)
        Set whether or not the variable is external. A variable is external if it is referenced from a language outside of Fathom. For example, a variable from the C language. Furthermore, a variable is external if it begins with an externally imported C file's name.

        For example: 
         import "externalFile.h";
 
 ...
 
 public static void main(String args[])
 {
        // This is the external variable declaration.
        externalFile.externalType varName;
        
        // This is the external variable assignment.
        varName = externalFile.variableInstance;
 }
        In this example, 'externalFile' is the C header file that is imported. 'variableInstance' is the name of a variable that is contained within the imported header file.
        Parameters:
        external - Whether or not the variable will be external.

      • isPrimitive

        public boolean isPrimitive()
        Get whether a variable is primitive or not. A variable is primitive if it has a primitive type AND is NOT an array. Arrays are NOT a primitive type.

        For the list of primitive values, see SyntaxUtils.isPrimitiveType(String).
        Returns:
        Whether a variable is primitive or not.

      • isConstant

        public boolean isConstant()
        Get whether or not the variable's value is constant. To see more detail, look at setConstant(boolean).
        Returns:
        Whether or not the variable's value is constant.

      • getConstantText

        public java.lang.String getConstantText()
        Get the C equivalent of the 'constant' keyword.
        Returns:
        The C equivalent of the 'constant' keyword.

      • setConstant

        public void setConstant(boolean constVal)
        Set whether or not the variable's value is constant.

        For example: 
         private constant int MAX_PEOPLE = 10;
        This variable is constant, as defined by the 'constant' keyword.
        Parameters:
        constVal - Whether or not the variable's value is constant.

      • isArray

        public boolean isArray()
        Get whether or not the variable is an array. A variable is an array if it has an array dimension of 1 or greater.
        Returns:
        Whether or not the variable is an array.

      • getArrayDimensions

        public int getArrayDimensions()
        Get the amount of dimensions that the array has, if any. For an example of what a array declarations and dimensions look like setArrayDimensions(int)
        Returns:
        The amount of dimensions that the array has, if any.

      • getArrayText

        The text that represents an array in the C language.
        Returns:
        The text that represents an array in the C language.

      • setArrayDimensions

        public void setArrayDimensions(int arrayDimensions)
        Set the amount of dimensions that the array has, if any.

        For example: 
         int array[][][];
        In the previous example, the variable "array" has three dimensions.
        Parameters:
        arrayDimensions - The amount of dimensions that the array has, if any.

      • setName

        public void setName(java.lang.String name,
           boolean forceOriginal)
        Set the name of the Variable. You specify whether or not you want the output in the C language to be the original to the given name, or if it will differentiate it.
        Parameters:
        name - The String to set as the new name.
        forceOriginal - Whether or not the name will be output in the c code verbatim.

      • setAttribute

        public void setAttribute(java.lang.String attribute)
        Set a specified attribute to true.

        For example: 
         private static int index;
        private sets the visibility of the declaration to private. static sets the variable as static.
        Parameters:
        attribute - The attribute to set true.

      • setAttribute

        public boolean setAttribute(java.lang.String attribute,
                   int argNum)
        Set a specified attribute to true.

        For example: 
         private static int index;
        private is the first attribute (index: 0) that sets the visibility of the declaration to private. static is the second attribute (index: 1) that sets the variable as static.
        Parameters:
        attribute - The attribute to set true.
        argNum - The index of the attribute in the order that it came in.

      • generateUseOutput

        public java.lang.String generateUseOutput()
        Generate the representation of when the variable is being used, in action, rather than being declared.

        For example:
         Person p;
 p.getName();
        The first line shows the declaration of the Variable. The second line demonstrates a "variable use" for the "p" variable. Essentially, the "variable use" output is exactly what it says, what the variable looks like when it is being used to do something.
        Overrides:
        generateUseOutput in class IdentifierNode
        Returns:
        What the variable looks like when it is being used to do something.

      • generateUseOutput

        public java.lang.String generateUseOutput(boolean pointer)
        Generate the representation of when the variable is being used, in action, rather than being declared.

        For example:
         Person p;
 p.getName();
        The first line shows the declaration of the Variable. The second line demonstrates a "variable use" for the "p" variable. Essentially, the "variable use" output is exactly what it says, what the variable looks like when it is being used to do something.
        Parameters:
        pointer - Whether or not the variable is to be accessed by a pointer.
        Returns:
        What the variable looks like when it is being used to do something.
